reviews.review_title: Once again, people take things way too seriously.
reviews.content: While this film is meant for kids, I as a 26 year old viewer, enjoyed this film all by myself. Keep in mind that I can watch intelligent, award-winning films that make me think about the future of the human race, but I don't want to do that all the time.And personally, the film does have some good values to be found, as well as some songs that, if they were sung by anyone else, I wouldn't touch them with a 20ft pole! To those who refuse to see this film based on what others say I say this, the Chipmunks have been around for 50+ years, and are a world renowned group. This is coming from someone who grew up with the old cartoons, but I realize that the image needed a change if it was to catch on with today's audience, just like it had to in the 1980's.This film, while not as good as the first one, is no where near as bad as it has been rated, and to me, those who give it a 2, 3, 4, or anything less than at least a 7, obviously have been brainwashed with way too much High School Musical or too many serious films and they expect everything to be a masterpiece.To anyone who actually uses their brain, please, chill out, relax, and enjoy the film.

reviews.review_title: Has the same pros and cons as the first movie- in short unexceptional but watchable
reviews.content: I am not sure which of the two is better, so I am going to say that in my eyes this sequel is on the same level as its predecessor albeit with one improvement. Neither movie is as good as the timeless TV show or the wonderful Chipmunk Adventure, but in many ways more than one both are cute and harmless movies without trying to be 5-star masterpieces.Alvin and the Chipmunks:The Squeakquel has cons that are similar to its predecessor. As with the first, the film is very predictable with some clichéd human characters and situations, though in fairness a lot of animated/live action films do have that problem as well. Also it does have some hits and misses in the script with some jokes that parents might groan at. The film is rather short and rushed as well.Faults aside, the film does have an improvement, the performance of Jason Lee as David. In the first he was miscast and out of his depth, here he is much more comfortable and relaxed. Visually and technically, I have little to fault it either. The photography and editing is crisp without being award-worthy, the location work is quite colourful and striking and the animation on the chipmunks again is spot on being very cute. The chipmunks are adorable with voices that are thankfully not irritating, and as with the first Alvin and the Chipmunks:The Squeakquel nails the personalities of the chipmunks, Theodore again being the best realised. And the soundtrack is very catchy, with tuneful melodies and sweet lyrics, which kids will love and adults will possibly tolerate too.Overall, unexceptional but watchable family entertainment. 6/10 Bethany Cox

reviews.review_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
reviews.content: ALVIN AND THE CHIPMUNKS 2! By: SteffiYou should see Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 . The movie is funnier than ever! I'm impressed of their job in the movie. The characters are Alvin,Simon,Theodore, & Elvanmor,Brittany,& Jeanette. My favorite character is Theodore because she is cute he is also a little fat. and loves his family like Alvin,& Simon. and he likes Elvanmor. for her friends. One reason is I like this movie is because they add many emotions I can think of like sad, happy,annoyed,desperate,and angry. When I saw the movie I laughed so hard I almost cried but not for sadness.This movie includes props and pranked stuff.THIS MOVIE IS AWESOME! They mostly include singing and dancing. The movie is so cool I didn't even finish my popcorn because I was so hooked in the movie when the movie was brand new. I would recommend 10 out of 10 stars! You should see Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 I recommend you go! Come on go!

reviews.review_title: Those chipmunks get nuts (Screen)
reviews.content: This was again the choice of the kid. A bit like the Russian roulette. So we ran in the cold to see a sequel about characters that I even didn't watch in their dull cartoons in my childhood.However, after the movie, we were happy. Those chipmunks have a lot of energy and they know how to put a mess! So, it's funny. Their voices are great even thought I couldn't escape a snooze after the school contest! For me, it was remembrances from "Roger Rabbit" but the movie is too cheap for a classic. For me, "Alvin" look like very much as a Saturday production for kids and surely not as a theater release! So far, we haven't watched the first one

reviews.review_title: So it's not Disney...
reviews.content: Okay,it's not Disney(not a bad thing,really) and the guys from "Roadside Romeo" did not work on it.Rhythm and Hues did a fantastic job with design and animation.I'm not sucking up,just the facts. The story and the humans in this film-different thing altogether.Someone got the Disney bug about putting their characters in a school setting.OK,kids can relate,and the cartoon series ended with the Chipmunks and Chipettes in school.The humans in the film-painful to watch really.Ethan Hawke did not learn anything from his loss of the Chipmunks.Dave is in hospital most of the time(thank goodness).The goober they have to fill in for him is a troglodyte.It may have been easier to take the cartoonishness of the human cast had it been done all CGI. I still loved the film for the moments where everything worked.I hope they get a better script next time!

reviews.review_title: Rather Disappointing
reviews.content: The predecessor for this film was adorable. This one is rather annoying. Children chipmunks finding their way through life is bad enough, but to have them in pubescent form, attempting some chipmunk version of Mating Habits of the Earthbound Human just doesn't make for "cute" anymore. This was just fair.After the joy we found in the first attempt, I expected much more from this one. But the joy was not there to be found. What was there was angst, bad decisions, stupidity, ego massaging, puffery, and deceit. This isn't a lesson for most kids, and by the time they get around to showing what a bad idea this all was, it's too little too late. The lesson is lost in the glitz and glamor of the life of the pop star culture.No wonder pop stars all go bad, if this is the kind of stuff they have to deal with 24/7.Further, the attire of the girl chipmunks is completely inappropriate, and the behaviors herein are NOTHING to be imitated by America's youth! Miley Cyrus' clothing line is bad enough! Enough is enough, people!I didn't like it.It rates a 3.7/10 from...the Fiend :.

reviews.review_title: Cute movie for toddlers and preschoolers
reviews.content: My son who is 4 years old loved it. Yes, from an adult's perspective the movie line is very similar to the first movie, but this is a def must see if you have small children. No profanity, popular songs, and a high speed chase keeps the little ones interested throughout this movie. I was able to sit through the entire movie and was mildly entertained. I wasn't on the verge of falling asleep nor was I on the edge of my seat, but keep in mind that this is geared towards children. I would definitely recommend seeing this movie if your children liked the first movie. If you are an adult and mildly liked the first movie and do not have kids and are thinking about going to see this movie, wait for it to come out on DVD. Overall I think this movie is still a good movie, just slightly below the first movie. In my opinion, I would have rather rented the DVD for myself, but with the kids involved this made for an excellent Father/Son night out at the movies. I am happy that I was able to take my son to see it tonight.

reviews.review_title: good kids & family movie
reviews.content: This was obviously meant for the kids and family set. As long as you come to the movie in that frame of mind, you will thoroughly enjoy this movie. Alvin and the Chipmunks are back in this sequel,er,squeakwel as Dave moves them to the States with the intention of sending them to school, he winds up in the hospital, they wind up in the care of his brother, and hilarious mayhem ensues as they try to fit in to high school. Hey, you try to be a chipmunk in high school! I loved the principal in this movie, and the "battle of the bands" scenes were great and funny. I also like the "chippettes." They were great. This is a good film for the kids and family-take your kids to see it! ** 1/2 out of ****

reviews.review_title: Please chipmunks don't be late
reviews.content: Those adorable singing chipmunks discovered by David Seville find they have some competition with a singing chipmunk trio known as the Chipettes who are girls. Kind of hard to keep your mind on school and performing with those chipmunk hormones kicking in.I did say school because Jason Lee as David has a broken leg and Simon, Theodore, and Alvin are in the charge of Seville's socially challenged nephew Zachary Levi. The boys have their usual problems of adjustments that humans do let alone rodents.In addition the Moriarty of the piece is their former manager David Cross is determined not to let the old chipmunk act steal the thunder of his new group.This second Alvin And The Chipmunks film, The Squeaksquel is funny in spots and adults might occasionally get a chuckle. But it really is strictly for little kids.

reviews.review_title: Just ok
reviews.content: Just like the first one it's just ok and has funny scenes I remember.

reviews.review_title: Best Movie of 2009
reviews.content: I'm not sure why all the hating on "Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel" by reviewers on this site. It's by far the most entertaining film of 2009.If you hate wet-your-paints funny humor, good musical harmony, and stories with substance, you will hate this film. If you enjoy being entertained on various levels and perhaps getting something to think about along the way you will LOVE this film.Part of me thinks it's about a bunch of adults who don't want to admit how dearly they love something from their childhood. After all, "Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel" is on target to be the #1 weekend movie. The kids aren't bringing themselves to the theaters folks.If you came on this site to see if you should go to this movie, you should go. Apparently most of the other reviewers wouldn't know good entertainment if it had fur and sang.

reviews.review_title: Great loved it but not as good as the first
reviews.content: I went to see this movie on the opening day first showing. in the theater with little kids it dawned on me this was meant for little kids. but it did not disappoint us older people. Anyone who has seen the original Chipmunks knows that this is just what they are: a silly comedy for kids that has no sex, violence, or foul language. The whole story outline wasn't the best but it has all the things that make the Chipmunks what they are. Little kids will love it and the adults won't mind watching it with them (though if they watch it too much it will get old). I would gladly see this movie again in fact i am and i think i will still laugh at the jokes and enjoy the movie.

reviews.review_title: Just another forgivable movie
reviews.content: The sequel of Alvin and the Chipmunks is pretty much the same as the first one but with the addition of the chipettes. A movie intended for children and maybe for those who like to remember their childhood. The plot is predictable and the story doesn't have nothing new to show. This time the chipmunks are force to go to school because David suffered and accident and where they meet the chipettes It has some funny moments, the animation for the chipmunks is good. Jason Lee, Justin Long, Matthew Gray Gubler and Jesse McCartney return as Dave, Alvin, Simon and Theodore respectively and with the addition of Christina Applegate, Anna Faris and Amy Phoeler making the voices of Brittany, Jeanette and Eleanor. Maybe the best of this movie is its soundtrack, with really good songs like You really got me from Van Halen and Single Ladies from Beyonce. To conclude, Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 is a movie you can enjoy with the family or for those that want to remember their childhood, if you're not either one of those, then you can wait for the DVD or just don't watch it. You won't lose anything important.

reviews.review_title: super movie
reviews.content: it is a super movie you will stand up and cheer that is how good this movie is i never saw a movie quite like this it is a wonderful movie i have never seen a movie this super this is what i call a great movie you just have to watch this wonderful movie it is the perfect Christmas movie and the perfect family film it is one of the best movies i have ever seen you just have to watch this amazing this is a outstanding movie it is a super movie go see this amazing movie today you want be sorry it is out of this world i never saw a movie like this it is like one of the best movies ever created you just have to watch this amazing movie this is a super family film it is a classic i never saw a movie like this before it is great go see this amazing movie today i like this movie a lot and so will you this is one of the best movies ever made have a great day everyone you want be sorry

reviews.review_title: For Alvin and the Chipmunk Fans Only...
reviews.content: Clearly, most of the people who rated this movie poorly are those who are unfamiliar with the Alvin and the Chipmunks brand. The plot of the this movie wasn't great, but the film was dead on with the way the main characters were portrayed. Alvin, the mischievous, always getting into trouble... Simon, the genius, going toe to toe against Alvin's shenanigans... and Theodore, the big-hearted, trying to keep the peace between his two brothers. Even Jason Lee is dead on as Dave.Some people commented on how 'crazy' it is for chipmunks to go to school with humans, but that's the whole point! It's already crazy that they talk, sing, wear clothes, and see a human as their dad, so what's one more thing? Besides, I do believe they went to school during the series in the 80's. If you had an issue with it being HIGH school, I can see that, because the chipmunks were suppose to be, in theory, comparable to kids 8-11 years old, so elementary school would have been more appropriate, but either way, if my memory serves me correctly, the original characters did go to school with HUMANS.The bottom line is that this movie just isn't for everyone. If Alvin and the Chipmunks were before or AFTER your time, then maybe you just won't get it. As a matter of fact, if you know you didn't grow up with Alvin and the Chipmunks yourself, then don't waste your time taking your kids to see the movie either, because you will surely ruin it for them. As a kid of the 80's, I don't really need of "thought-provoking" Academy Award plot... I just like seeing the revamped animation of some of my old favorites on the big screen.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable...NOT!!!
reviews.content: Absolutely horrible! This is without a doubt the worst movie I have ever seen in my entire life!!! Now in this, we don't just get Alvin and the chipmunks, but we also get the "chipettes". Dave, played by Jason Lee who you can clearly see doesn't want to be there. He's like, alright, you got me once you're not gonna get me again. So he's in one scene in the beginning and then you never see him again. Now Dave wants them to get an education so they go to high school and...and CHIPMUNKS DON'T GO TO HIGH SCHOOL!!! It would be different if it were a chipmunk high school but no, they go to a human high school where they have to worry about not getting stepped on. And then the jocks, now these are the wimpiest jocks i've ever seen. They're extremely jealous of the chipmunks for no reason and start picking on them. So they want to beat up...chipmunks doesn't really make a lot of sense. And meanwhile they have to win a contest to...(chuckles) get back the school music program. I can't stand thinking about this movie! The writing was so bad that in the theater I wanted to scream out "WHO WROTE THIS!!!" The acting was terrible. And nothing in this movie made sense at all. I kinda liked the first one but this was complete trash and again my least favorite movie of all time, Thank You.

reviews.review_title: must see even if u didn't see the first
reviews.content: i think the movie was great not as good as the first one but still really good when i was in the cinema a lot of the laughs came from the young kids but there were adults that i heard laugh so its not a movie that will only make the kids laugh the story line was alright not as good as first and i would have liked to see more of Dave but we saw a lot of Toby instead anyway it was still a great movie has some funny stuff in it such as Theodore when he says shes practicing pole dancing it was random and you wouldn't expect that coming its a movie you must see if your a fan of the chipmunks i give it a 7/10 =D

reviews.review_title: harmless Chipmunks for the kids
reviews.content: Dave (Jason Lee) is in the hospital after the Chipmunks cause an accident at their Paris concert. Aunt Jackie is supposed to be the next caretaker but the boys quickly send her to the hospital. Then it's up to Jackie's incompetent video game obsessed grandson Toby (Zachary Levi). The boys have to go to high school. Dr. Rub (Wendie Malick) is the principal. All the girls love the Chipmunks and the boys hate them for it. Ian Hawke (David Cross) is living in the record company basement vowing revenge and living off of garbage. Then the Chipettes, Brittany, Jeanette, and Eleanor, show up looking for representation.I don't know if Jason Lee had better things to do. Sending the Chipmunks to high school has some potential. Adding the Chipettes should double the fun. The execution does not pan out exactly. It's bearable for adults and Chipmunk wacky for the kids. It has a High School Musical feel but not as good. There are probably a couple of familiar faces in the teenagers' crowd. This is harmless and safe for the kids.

reviews.review_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
reviews.content: The first film, based on the musical band and the children's cartoon was tedious and annoying, this sequel I was hoping would be better, as the critics thought it was, from director Betty Thomas (Private Parts, Doctor Dolittle, John Tucker Must Die). Basically after brother pop stars, the Chipmunks, Alvin (Justin Long), Simon (Matthew Gray Gubler) and Theodore (Jesse McCartney), put their carer Dave Seville (Jason Lee) in the hospital, they need someone else to look after them. It appears that their Aunt Jackie (Kathryn Joosten) is the person who is going to do that, but she ends up in hospital too, and twenty-something games nerd, Dave's nephew Toby (Zachary Levi) is the only one left. Arrangements are made for the Chipmunks to put aside their stardom and go to school, tasked by super fan principal to help save the music program with the upcoming battle of the bands competition with a funding prize of $25,000. Meanwhile, the Chipmunks old meanie Ian Hawke (David Cross) is living in the basement of JETT records on scraps from dumpsters having lost his reputation, but his luck changes when he finds three female chipmunks, the Miller sisters Brittany (Christina Applegate), Eleanor (Amy Poehler) and Jeanette (Anna Faris). The Chipettes as they call themselves turned up in a parcel to find Ian, and after proving themselves to be good singers, he hires them and with some lies to convince them he still has a career, he starts scheming his way back into business. The Chipmunks are having a hard time getting on in school with bullies and jocks bringing them down, but they are perked up when the Chipettes turn up to put themselves forward to represent the school. The principal decides the only way to settle which of the two furry bands should represent the school in the competition is to have a sing off contest, and the winner will do it. Alvin is neglecting his brothers, trying to fit in with the guys who were originally picking on him, and Ian is forcing the Chipettes to change the way they are, by having Brittany as the lead singer and the other two just back up. The Chipettes know that Ian is nasty when he locks them in a cage, and Alvin goes to rescue them just before the singing competition, and they arrive just in time for both the Chipmunks and Chipettes to perform. In the end, all the apologies are made, Ian loses his career again, Dave, out of hospital watches the six furry friends perform, and allows the three newbies to stay with them. Also starring Kevin G. Schmidt as Ryan, Chris Warren Jr. as Xander and Bridgit Mendler as Becca. The choice of songs with the helium voices, including "You Really Got Me", "You Spin Me Round (Like A Record)", "Put Your Records On", "Hot N Cold", "Single Ladies (Put A Ring On It)" and "We Are Family" are certainly more fun to hear. The squeaky voices are still a little annoying, the live actors are cheesy, and the story is patchy and could have used a little work, but I suppose it is a tiny bit better than the predecessor, an alright part-animated comedy adventure. Okay!

reviews.review_title: Lighten up folks—it's just a kids' film about singing chipmunks!
reviews.content: The first Alvin and the Chipmunks movie took the tried and tested rock 'n' roll fable route, charting its talented rodents' rise to fame, their big break, the bitter struggle with the many temptations of stardom, and their inevitable exploitation by unscrupulous business types. Elation, heartache, excitement, despair, fear, joy: it was all there, along with gags about poo.The plot for The Squeakquel—a formulaic high-school based morality tale about the importance of loyalty—isn't quite as strong and the film definitely lacks the freshness of the original, but there is still enough good stuff here to warrant a watch, especially if you're already a fan of the furry trio.Betty Thomas does a decent enough job in the director's chair, delivering plenty of not too sophisticated laughs and lots of energetic musical numbers, the effects are on par with the original, and the cast all put in more than adequate performances (David Cross as evil Ian providing my favourite gag right at the end of the film). On top of all that, Alvin, Theodore and Simon are joined by the slick high-pitched harmonies of the Chipettes, an equally talented trio of female chipmunks—bookish Jeanette, big-boned Eleanor, and sexy Brittany (errr... did I say sexy? I meant cute. Time to go now, I think!).

reviews.review_title: Very meh
reviews.content: So forgettable of a sequel that I already forgot what the plot was by the time I was finished watching other than the fact that it has girl chipmunks in it.

reviews.review_title: Come on and shake what your mama gave ya!
reviews.content: Gosh, enough is enough. Those lovable singing chipmunks featuring Alvin(Justin Long)try and put their musical career on hold to extend their book learning. They return to school to find the music program is having money problems and put the school's hope in a battle of the bands competition. Alvin, Theodore and Simon seem to have it in the bag so to speak; but they are going to meet their match in the Chippettes(voiced by Christina Applegate, Amy Poehler and Anna Faris). Compromises will have to be made to keep everyone happy. Manager Dave(Jason Lee)has less screen time in this "squeakquel". Other players: David Cross, Wendie Malick and Zachary Levi. I really can't see why; but you know good and well that there has to be a third outing in the planning. Money is money; and there is definitely an audience. ALVIN!

reviews.review_title: Alvin
reviews.content: When the second Alvin and the chipmunk movie first came out, my two sisters and I went to go see it together, just like we went to go see the first movie together. Even though the three of us are in our early twenties.. we still had fun going to see both of the movies together. This movie was great. But I did not think it was as good as the first movie. I liked the first Alvin and the chipmunk movie better than the second one. I would definitely recommend this movie to other people. The end of the movie was my favorite. Also, just watching the reaction of the younger boys and girls in the theater and their reaction to some of the parts in the movie, was amazing and funny.

reviews.review_title: Chipmunk Dung.
reviews.content: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009): Dir: Betty Thomas / Cast: Jason Lee, David Cross, Zachary Levi, Wendie Malick, Anjelah Johnson: One could say that the budget went to the guy who came up with the subtitle. As lame as it is, it certainly surpasses anything the screenplay possessed. After Dave has an accident, the three singing chipmunks are sent to live with an aunt and go to school. Then she has an accident due too Dave's idiotic nephew. After a bout with bullies they are set to help the school win a talent contest. Directed by Betty Thomas with Alvin, Simon and Theodore looking fantastic but the story is lame. Thomas has directed a broad range of films from the excellent Howard Stern bio-comedy Private Parts to the Sandra Bullock rehab 28 Days. This is hardly one of her superior projects. Jason Lee as Dave spends the whole film laid up, which is probably for the better seeing that he is second to CGI chipmunks. David Cross plays an idiotic villain out to exploit a female chipmunk band. He must endure the embarrassment of dressing up as a female chipmunk that looks straight out of Donnie Darko's worst nightmares. Zachary Levi plays Dave's lazy nephew who sleeps and plays video games. One supposes that anything is better than being part of this film. Terrible family entertainment that should squeak underneath one's tires as the car backs out of the driveway. Score: 2 / 10

reviews.review_title: This is my toddler's favorite movie
reviews.content: My two-year-old has claimed this as the movie she must watch once a day. This is a well-executed PG movie where the jokes are funny to the adults and the kids still giggle. To properly enjoy such a movie, one must simply lighten up and enjoy something cute for a couple hours. I am saddened that so many children's movies have lower scores just because it's the grown-ups that place the ratings. In my toddler's eyes this movie gets all ten fingers and all ten toes, and thank goodness she picked a film Mommy and Daddy don't mind sitting through again and again. Plus we don't have chipmunks in Hawaii so it's awesome for her to learn about them. Yes she knows its not normal for animals to talk, lol.Bottom line: how can you hate furry dancing chipmunks?

reviews.review_title: Pretty harmless, it's like a high school jock picking on a chipmunk... wait a minute
reviews.content: I guess America will never be sick of the Chipmunks, though who am I kidding? I always watched the cartoon when I was a kid. Of course I saw the movie a few years ago and was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't a bad film. I was worried about the CGI and thought it would be cheesy, but it wasn't all that bad. There were even some great catchy songs that you found yourself singing too as well. So the now we have the sequel, this is where I was starting to wonder if this was more meant for money. We have some pretty well known actors playing the chipmunks and the chipettes, which I thought was a bit silly since their voices are put through a synthesizer anyways, so what's the point of having a big name when you already have Jason Lee? This played just like a typical chipmunk episode and I wasn't that impressed with it. Not as bad as you'd think, but still this movie needed some major work, even if it is meant for the kids, which we know this was more for the fans.During the Chipmunks' benefit concert David is injured. Dave must recuperate and is forced to leave his aunt to look after the Chipmunks. Arrangements are also made for them to go to school. After another accident, the Chipmunks are left in the care of Toby. Meanwhile, Ian Hawke lives in the basement of JETT Records. Three singing female chipmunks, also known as the Chipettes, emerge and Ian hires them as plot to get back at the Chipmunks and revive his career. While at school, the Chipmunks are bullied by jocks and visit the principal's office. They discover that the principal is a huge fan and wants them to help raise money for the music program by participating in a contest. Meanwhile, when Ian receives his daily newspaper, he is shocked to find the Chipmunks on the front page. After he reads the story, he quickly sends the Chipettes to school. The Chipmunks and the Chipettes will compete against each other in the Battle of the Bands contest.So while the movie doesn't fall flat on it's face, it definitely was not needed. There are moments where I thought it was a little too silly and predictable, not to mention I'm confused how a high school girl finds a chipmunk to be hot? The jocks pick on the chipmunks which I thought was silly, I mean, really? Let's be serious, let's say that this is a real life situation and talking and singing chipmunks really exist, how could you possibly feel tough by picking on a chipmunk? But I do have to admit that the meeting between the chipmunks and the chipettes was pretty cute. The chipette's rendition of Single Ladies was pretty catchy. I had a couple of laughs with Ian trying to cover the concert when the girls back out. Like I said I think this was more meant for the kids than the adults and also of course more for the money, but I guess it's pretty harmless fun. Hard to hate this movie when the leading characters are singing chipmunks, they were awesome in the 80's and they're still pretty cool to this day. However I would recommend this movie more for the kids vs. the adults, at least the adults still have the cartoon with "Alvin, Simon, Theodore! Doo Doo, Doo Doo Doo Doo, Doo Doo, Doo Doo Doo Doo!". Well, you get the idea.5/10

reviews.review_title: Simply enthralling rodent fun
reviews.content: These cheeky chipmunks just cannot stay out of trouble! This time, the three fellas (Alv, Si and Theo) come up against 3 steaming chipmunks (check it) known as the Chippetes. In order to win the battle of the bands, they have to up their game and give the performance of their wild lives. I will not lie to you: it's a very, very tense movie. I was on the edge of my seat when Alvin stepped up to the mic for the last song. I was thinking to myself 'Alvin and co! You only get one shot! Do not miss your chance to blow! This opportunity comes once in a lifetime yo!' I won't ruin the ending for you all, but let's just say we could well be expecting a new litter of chipmunks in the future (if you catch my drift...)Information about chipmunks: http://chirpiechipmunkz.webs.com/aboutchipmunks.htmMy rating - 9/10. Would have given it 10 but unfortunately it only lasted for 88 minutes and as you can imagine, was left wanting much much more. We want trilogy! We want trilogy!HH

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the first one but still a lot of fun,
reviews.content: Alvin And The Chimpmunks 2:The Squeakquel is a good movie with enjoyable and funny stuff but I found it to be a disappointment compared to the original Alvin And The Chimpmunks,I don't think the storyline is as good and you don't see too much of Dave.When Dave is put into hospital, his cousin or brother (they don't tell you) has to take care of them and Dave tells him to put Alvin,Simon and Teador into school,were they deal with a lot of bully's and Ian returns to try make them lose their fame by three singing girl chipmunks,the Chipettes!-DILLON HARRIS

reviews.review_title: The Vidiot Reviews...
reviews.content: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The SqueakquelUsually, when you place three wild rodents in a recording studio surrounded by expensive equipment and press record, all you get is the sound of them chewing through the microphone cord, followed by a crackle of electricity, and three death rattles. However, in this furry family film, when you put a trio of tree dwellers in a studio, you get a bunch of high-pitched cover songs.With Dave (Jason Lee) in hospital after a chipmunk related accident, the boys, Alvin, Simone and Theodore (Justin Long, Matthew Gray Gubler and Jesse McCartney), are entrusted to his nephew, Toby (Zachary Levi). Required to attend high school, the Chipmunks make a big splash on campus when they're asked to save the school's music program. But before the boys can collect the prize money, they must best an all-female chipmunk group (Amy Poehler, Anna Faris and Christina Applegate).A perfunctory sequel to the 2007 original, The Squeakquel maintains the same low expectations as its predecessor: the story is sorry, the songs are boring, and the star- studded vocal cast is superfluous.Besides, the only time you're libel to find chipmunks inside of a high school is when the cafeteria is serving mystery meat for lunch. (Red Light)

reviews.review_title: Only bearable because of the Chippettes...
reviews.content: With this "squeakuel", I think this incarnation of Alvin and the Chipmunks has run its course. This Part 2 was really lame. Even my three kids with me did not react too much to the supposedly "funny" scenes. I was positively bored silly for most of the movie. Alvin's naughtiness is very nasty here in this movie, and unfunny for me.The only time my attention perked up was that first song number by the Chippettes. Their harmonized version of "Put Your Records On" was very cute. Their take on "Single Ladies" is also quite fine. In contrast, all the songs by the Chipmunks sounded very old and dated. The Chippettes are the only positive aspect of this movie. The special cameo of young Filipina singer Charice singing Alicia Keys' "No One" merits an additional star.After the movie, my kids only remembered a scene about underwear wedgies, and a part where a grown man wears a dress while doing hand puppets. I only remember laughing once, and that was a scene with Wendie Malick (Nina Van Horn of TV's "Just Shoot Me") as the school principal jumping up and down with glee (yeah, stupid scene, hehe). If you think those memorable scenes sound bad, you can imagine what more the rest of this film!

reviews.review_title: A great, fantastic sequel
reviews.content: I really like how the surprise introduction of the Chipettes saves this film from being too boring as the beginning just shows the chipmunks wrecking havoc and causing trouble, this time, Toby (unlike Dave) rarely cares about their mischief but later on he does become protective and caring and starts taking on some responsibility. The Locker Reveal scene in the film was probably the most heartwarming and romantic part, when the Chipmunks and Chipettes meet each other in the school hallway for the first time, they both are love struck upon seeing each other (look at their faces, they flash toothy smiles at each other) but it is ruined when Ian manipulates the Chipettes into making them not trust the Chipmunks and make them think they are evil. Ian's role is quite evil ad I think this will terrify the kids. Jason Lee's role was reduced significantly here, he barely appears but I'm glad Mike Mitchell expanded his role in the third film. Overall, this film may be flawed but it's freshly squeezed comedic energy and great family fun.

reviews.review_title: Non Fat Cake !
reviews.content: The he and she chipmunks are adorable. The variety of their songs is amusing. Zachary Levi is cute and funny. The colors are soothing, and the comedy is mild.The script provided nice time. I loved smartly written moments like how the nerd boy, played by Levi, had to supersede the chipmunks at the party with his singing, so his old flame got the chance to hear his feelings for her rightly. Plus smartly made moments, like the mission of rescuing the she chipmunks with a motorcycle chase.So, eventually, what on earth the haters was yakking about??!!You know what are the real problems of this movie? I'll tell. Not having Jason Lee as the co-lead; which was done for never-understood reason. One fart joke I hated. And the fact of the movie as short.However, it does satisfy me the way it is, and clearly for the aforementioned reasons. Therefore, some reviewers made me angry with remarks like: "Terrible Movie". Well, I think the approach, that these reviewers use to evaluate such a movie, is the real "Terrible"!This is light fun, as non fat cake. It worked / works / will work for me. Who can't feel joy in heart by the chipmunks singing Beyoncé Knowles's Single Ladies?!

reviews.review_title: Alvin is a cannibal confirmed
reviews.content: With a plot that's ore pointless one second to the next and its irritable stars being more irritable than ever, Alvin and the Chipmunks The Squeakquel certainly never improves upon its counterpart and instead makes for a film that only feels fun to watch in an ironic sense. When it comes to these films, it's hard not to comment on the use of the CGI chipmunks throughout the film- and somehow the CGI this time around ended up getting both better and worse. It feels like video game level graphics at times, never blending in with its surroundings and clunking around at almost laughable levels. Other times the CGI is so detailed and in depth it feels like a joke, as if these were completely different characters than what we just saw 10 seconds ago. As with before, the acting is pretty bad this time around, although Zachary Levi is thankfully a lot more tolerable than Jason Lee's overdone performance in the last film. The plot in this film is also absolutely ridiculous, pointless, and quite honestly full of plotholes- not that any younger viewers would care- but you can't help but wonder towards the end why the hell any of this had to happen in the first place. The establishment of highschool characters make the film feel even more joke like- its characters soon being made of a cast of incredibly obvious stereotypes that can just prove to be hard to watch at times. The only thing I can comment on positively in this film is that, again, a few of the songs are catchy and the film is rather entertaining throughout. But as mindlessly entertaining as it may be, it still can't get the thoughts out of my head about interspecies relationships of chipmunks and high schoolers- and the several R-rated movie references that Alvin makes for some unknown reason. In the end, Alvin and the Chipmunks The Squeakquel is a sequel best left ignored and offers nothing to the subpar original than the addition of a wacky title.My Rating: 3.7/10.

reviews.review_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)
reviews.content: A bit of stupid repetitive fun. We are introduced to the Chippettes and the entire story is pretty much the same. We find The Chipmunks now at school, and due to some embarrassment it seems as though Jason Lee found a loophole in his contract to be mostly absent. Considering the chipmunks became superstars at the end of the first film, it was strange to see them settling in at a school and auditioning for a school competition. It also gave a good message about sometimes helping others. Alvin is an annoying prick for most of it, but Theodore is just insanely cute. David Cross puts in the exact same performance as last time. Although it is harmless family fun, the stupidly dated movie references and same story mean that the only reason to see this is if you are a huge Chippettes fan.

reviews.review_title: Tainted by fame; A Cautionary Tail.
reviews.content: See; even I can do puns!I know they're singing chipmunks, but they really overplayed the musical angle this time, for me. I was hugely surprised by the original and really enjoyed it, despite being a 29 year old man, but this one is just a pale imitation.I don't know whether it was Jason Lee's decision not to be involved as much the second time around, but the fact that the story has "Dave" on the periphery of things really hurts the film, overall.I like the whole brothers/family dynamic... Nobody is endearing when they get entangled with the trappings of fame - not even chipmunks.It seems like whenever a writing team runs out of ideas, the easiest thing to do is go bigger. Then unfortunately, the sense of brotherhood and camaraderie gets lost.Don't make fun of me for talking about 'brotherhood' and 'camaraderie' in relation to chipmunks! You can blame my over-inflated expectations on the high standards set by the first film; standards which were not met, when it came to this 'squeakuel'.

reviews.review_title: a cute kid's film but also for the young at heart
reviews.content: I will be 42 next month, so every once in a while it behooves me to watch a film that makes me feel like a kid again. I am probably one of the last people to see this film in a theatre, I saw it at a very cheap theatre that shows second run movies. I see that viewers only gave it a 3.5 rating and almost a third rated it a one on a scale of 1 to 10! Come on people it isn't that bad. Its a cute film you can take your kids to see, how often does that come along? I was shocked that there wasn't one curse word in it. I can almost picture the script conferences when they were making this film. They said hey if three cute chipmunks are good, lets add three more and make them female! What a novel concept.My main complain is that Jason Lee's character (Dave) was offscreen so much of the time and I thought Toby was a poor substitute. Lets face it, Alvin, Simon and Theodore need a more positive role model. I had almost forgotten what a pathetic loser Ian was until I watched this. When I first saw The Chipmunks in 2007, I thought he was one of the creepiest looking bad guys I've ever seen in a kid's movie. SPOILER ALERT, he even locks those three cute girl chipmunks in a cage just like he did in the first film. He gets a great comeuppance in the end, it involves his groin. The musical numbers are great and I like how this film spoofs high school life. Anyway, a wonderful way to spend 80 minutes.

reviews.review_title: This movie has some purpose...
reviews.content: Bottom Line: This movie is 100% for the purpose of keeping your children quiet, and for the actors to get a paycheck.This piece of garbage has no qualities of an actual respected piece of work besides the fact that it has a beginning and an ending.This should be an inspiration to all of those out there trying to get a script read by Hollywood...Jesus, if this can make it on the big screen then I guess anything can.Amy Poehler and Anna Faris were probably getting drunk before doing the voice-overs, what kind of actor would actually take this production seriously? It was only made because there was a contract to make it and everyone desperately needs money.I must stop writing now, I can't believe I just took 3 minutes out of my day to think about this movie again.I gave it 2 stars because they have some decent names involved

reviews.review_title: Since when do squirrels go to school?
reviews.content: I'm not sure where to begin with this - just the word "squeakquel" made me cringe.Three digital rodents play guitar, go to school, and create merry hell, all for the benefit of the "holiday season" fans that helped make the original Chipmunks film a "global sensation" worth £350 million. That's not incredible; it's criminal.

reviews.review_title: Ridiculously ridiculous
reviews.content: Went to see the movie with my 12y.o and 9y.o kids. The movie even bored them to tears. Slightly more entertaining for the 12y.o daughter cos she knows couple of hit songs. The storyline is super ridiculous. Chipmunks going to highschool???? Cmon!!! The acting is also bogus. I think its totally pointless of putting big names to voice the chipmunks as it will be altered to high pitch anyway.The computer graphics and the artists however deserve a recognition. The mimic and movement are superbly rendered. That's probably the only good note about the movie. My suggestion: don't bring above 4.y.o. Better save the money for their college fund.

reviews.review_title: Another Film With a Dull School Film
reviews.content: The first film has weirded me out uncomfortably. This one has made me sure of what kind of movie it is, and it is a sequel that nobody asked for. Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakwuel is a very unpleasant sequel that would much rather rely on being a jukebox musical and feature goofy gags instead of telling a good story and show its purpose of its existence in the first place. And I would like to state that as a school movie, it barely has any story to it. All the chipmunks have ever done is go through exactly the scenarios in many of school movies before. They meet the girls (which would be the Chipettes in this case), one of them ditches the trio to play sports, and they struggle with a music competition to win the money for the school. That's all we ever gotten, it wouldn't have much of a purpose for the sequel. The same can be said for the characters that are either pointless or completely selfish. And even the direction made the movie seem more of a dance party with a bunch of slapstick instead of a legit movie. I'll give that at least it's not the worst movie based on a cartoon (since Dragonball Evolution came out the same year), but it won't help that this is a painfully average sequel. I would simply recommend to not watch it for how a bland school film it is, but I can only recommend this for those that actually like the first film. I'm saying this since I know there probably may be some people that are nostalgic for this. But for someone as myself that has grown out the entire movie franchise, the thing to describe is pointless and average. This is the kind of school I would drop out.

reviews.review_title: It would have made a good DVD movie but this is not for theaters
reviews.content: The film is cheap and it has the feel of a movie that was sent to DVD. If it was just for DVD and Blue-Ray I would understand, but this just shouldn't have been made for theaters. It isn't horrible, but it is pretty bad. The jokes aren't funny at all. The Chipmunks aren't charming just annoying, but on the other hand we have the Chipettes. I like these characters. They are not there to say bad jokes. They are there to sing and that is by far the best thing about the movie. I couldn't help but tap my feet a little bit. The CGI on the Chipmunks is not good, but the CGI on the Chipettes I found a lot better. The movie also moves very slow. I found myself almost falling asleep a few times. Overall the film isn't horrible, but it is bad. As a DVD movie it's OK, but as a film in the theaters it fails.1 and 1/2 stars out of 4

reviews.review_title: Repetition... Repetition... Repetition... and Repetition...
reviews.content: I went to see thiz movie with no expectation. I think all things that they want to show us, it has already appeared in the first movie. So thiz "Squeakquel" is only a repetition of what we have seen before. The movie is still played by Jason Lee and David Cross. The Alvin Character is voiced by Justin Long. The former Director Tim Hill who also directed "Garfield" (2004) now is replaced by Betty Thomas. It's very obvious that the moviemaker's intention is to refresh things up by the appearance of new characters, the Chippetes (the girl's version of the Chipmunks). Members of the Chippetes are Brittany (Christina Applegate), Jeanette (Anna Faris), Eleanor (Amy Poehler). We certainly recognize the trio as creditable Comediennes. I think in some ways, the movie is less musical than the first one. It looks like the Chippetes performance is based on the nowadays hip hop's style. If we look at the human characters, Zachary Levi seems to have more proportion than Jason Lee, both of them don't make us stunned by their performances. Their roles can be replaced easily by other Actors. In the end, I have to say that thiz kind of movie is definitely just for fun.Visit My Blog on JONNY'S MOVEE : http://jonnyfendi.blogspot.com

reviews.content: For the first 15 minutes I was thinking, this is kinda better than the 1st one?But then as the movie went on I realised it's just exactly the same thing beat for beat as before.

reviews.review_title: Not bad for kids
reviews.content: After watch it with adult mind no wonder the rating is so bad. But this is kids film, if you go watch this film with your adult mind no way you enjoy it, but if you go watch the film and know what you gonna expect, trust me this film pretty good. Maybe not the best film ever but its not bad, sometime we laughing, and if you say no joke is funny you lying. I pretty sure you laugh here and there. I do laugh with some joke, even it is stupid but sometime stupid joke still funny, and I see kids enjoy the film and I believe they enjoy it because they think its good film for them. So with right set of mind this film is quite good.

reviews.review_title: Just like the first movie but worse!
reviews.content: Okay, we're all going to have to admit this at some point, Alvin and the Chipmunks was an okay movie but does the sequel (or squeakquel) match up to the first? Do most sequels ever? The story was below mediocre and basically goes over old ground with a couple of things added to it, one being the Chipettes which is basically a female version of Alvin and the Chipmunks. The acting was below average, I remember it being much better in the first movie and the characters can be annoying at times but there were a couple of scenes when they were funny. The one person who extremely annoyed me constantly was the villain of the movie, all I wanted to do was put a sock in his mouth to shut him up. The animation was done very well and the way they mixed live-action with CGI was done great.There were a couple of funny moments in the movie but other than that, it felt like it was trying too hard. This will definitely entertain children but adults may find this an irritating bore in some parts. It depends on if you liked the Alvin and the Chipmunk cartoons. I used to love watching the cartoons when I was a kid and when the first movie was released, I watched and enjoyed it but watching the second one, I felt that the sequel was pointless. It's been done before but this time, there's the Chipettes. They didn't really add much to the movie in my opinion, it was just a basic repeat of the first movie with females (they're looking for stardom, finds manager, blah blah blah). There were one or two funny scenes but other than that, instantly forgettable as soon as the movie ends.Read more reviews on: www.dudedazzmoviereviews.wordpress.com

reviews.review_title: Another despicable Hollywood kids film.
reviews.content: In a nutshell (pun intended) this is A movie with nothing more than some really high pitch voices that sound funny. Add some childishly cheap computer graphics, And then talk about sex, And show dishonest and mischievous behavior. This movie tries to play like its a harmless kids film. When in reality the concepts reinforced over and over again in this film are to be disobedient. The use of sexual connotation is rampant. I see parents right review after review of how harmless and okay for kids this film is. These are the same parents who let their children watch anything Disney puts out and allow their children to listen to Britney Spears, And Christina Aguilera (both of whom were mousekateers) . This sort of material is down right dubious and anyone who cant see that, Cant see the forest through the trees.

reviews.review_title: Good family movie
reviews.content: Love the songs and also love the chipettes. I remember that the book was literally like my favourite book I had.

reviews.review_title: The Squekwal you know it's going to be good
reviews.content: I loved this movie it had the cute and innocence of the old chipmunks and enough modernization to be a great film. I would have to say the visual effects on the chipmunks was greatly improved. It seems as though the chipettes were made to look more fluffy and cute than the chipmunks. it was a good idea to introduce the chipettes. It also seems this movie showed a more aggressive Simon speaking of him I noticed that Simonand and Jenette never actually talked to each other until the end of the movie and it was over the phone so that might not count. I can't wait to see what they do for a third movie I think it should revolve more around the chipmunks and chipettes relationship's's.

reviews.review_title: Better than The Dark Knight we need more movies like this..
reviews.content: To start me off we have some great sequels. Aliens, The Dark Knight, Lord of the Rings: Return of the King and T-2. All those movies look like crap compared to Alvin and the Chipmunks 2. Alvin and the Chipmunks was great, absolutely fantastic. BUT Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 might be better. Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 features Jason Lee as Dave in yet another Oscar worthy role. Jason Lee has the amazing ability to show a great amount of emotion and just the power of acting. I'm very upset he will not be receiving an Oscar for the role of Dave. Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 also best be taking home a visual effects Oscar, the visuals are amazing and the chipmunks look amazing. The writing for the film is also very well done. The dialogue fits in very well and just makes the film better than it already is. This movie might be better than the first one and should get Best Picture. What makes me upset is that the movie didn't even got nominated for Best Picture. Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 is a great movie with wonderfully amazing acting, screenplay, visuals, directing, writing and just all around entertaining movie. I could go on with everything great about Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 because it is such an amazing movie. Alvin and the chipmunks is better than "The Good, The Bad and The Ugly." Alvin and the Chipmunks 2 gets an A+. I AM AN IDIOT AND MY REVIEW SUCKS IM ALSO LIAR. THANK YOU.

reviews.review_title: And yet I bought the DVD
reviews.content: This may be the first bad movie to gross $500 million. Gone with the Wind, The Sound of Music and the Chipmunk Squeakquel. It has severe plot flaws - why are they in high school? Goes for numerous cheap jokes - passing gas and falling down. Dave was so embarrassed about the movie he committed cinematic suicide within the first 3 minutes and limited his on screen appearances to less than 4 minutes thereafter. The movie tries to address teen angst and even does that poorly. And yet...I bought the DVD. I could blame it on the fact that my 4-year old thinks it's neat, or that my wife's name is Jeanette so I could relate to one of the characters, but I like the occasional...very occasional really good spots.Watch it once and don't do it again.
Not the movie that we want; but the movie that we need.

Although not the best of the 3, the film is still a stellar animated adventure. Review by Logan Cornn.

Drawing near to the pointy, frayed nerved end of these particularly scorching summer school holidays, parents begin the search for anything to entertain and cool down their bored wards. 

Providing this single elusive moment of quiet relief is the local fully air-conditioned cinema.  With a seemingly endless stream of children's entertainment the only need greater than the parents to entertain children is Hollywood studio's insatiable passion to regurgitate old themes in vain attempts to satisfy both parents and children alike. 

Ravishing the treasured childhood archives of Generation X and Y this year alone we have re-imagings of Transformers, Fame, Footloose, Where the wild things are, Nightmare on Elm Street, the list just keeps going.  Safe to say, however, hands down, this has to be the worst and if it wasn't bad enough to breathe CGI life into a trio of singing rodents once, they have added insult to injury and do it twice and made it a sextet.

For most readers an intro into the concept of the chipmunks is not required, but for those of you doing slightly more interesting things than watching Saturday morning cartons between 1985 and 1989, the chipmunks consist of three preteen squirrel-like rodent brothers who become international singing sensations and torment their adoptive human father Dave on a regular basis.

The story for this chapter ; After a chipmunk-induced accident leaves Dave (Jason Lee) in traction, chipmunks Alvin (the brash one), Simon (the brainy one) and Theodore (the chubby one) are placed in the unwilling care of a half witted twenty-something family screw-up Toby (Zachary Levi). 

Forced to return to school (surprisingly, high school) the boys reluctantly put aside there musical superstardom, until amazingly enough, the new principle Dr. Rubin (wonderfully played by Wendie Malick) recognises the boys, and quickly bribes them with the task of saving the school's suffering music program by winning a local Battle-of-the-Bands competition. 

With the grand prize being $25,000 (the exact amount needed), news circulates reaching their ridiculously destitute scheming ex-agent and nemesis from the first film, Ian Hawke (David Cross). Determined to exact revenge on the chipmunks, Ian enrols a rival girl-rodent trio of counterparts known as The Chipettes - Brittany, Eleanor and Jeanette into the same school, pitting the groups against eachother.

 
Romantic and musical sparks are ignited when the Chipmunks and Chipettes square off. Will the boys learn their lessons about family and friends and figure out that there is more to life than playing Wii and performing at the Staples Centre?

The slapstick middle-brow mayhem is well animated for the majority but distinctly goofy. The always charmingly mediocre concept of whiny, serenading rodents found its place on the 80's small screen and that is where the fuzzy pawed heroes should have remained. 

Battering viewers with good morals like; beating someone is not the same as winning, self-absorption cause's pain and family comes first, the dramatic contrast to the overly sexualised female Chipettes and overt product placements is a complete turn off.

Not content with just patronising children, the film becomes simply unbearable for parents when the stereotyped, helium voiced, trash-talking fur-balls rattle off a barrage of rip-off quotes from highly inappropriate adult films like Silence of the lambs and Taxi driver.  

A prerequisite for those over the age of 12, earplugs should be sold at the door and warnings should be plastered across the trailers regarding hearing loss and headaches. Still unclear to me is how its 2007 predecessor "Alvin" cleared a cool $217 million at the US box office alone, a sheer mystery. 

The surprising array of stars is a definite plus but their talents were dreadfully unrealised. Jason Lee obviously only appeared for one day of shooting due to contractual obligation and was quickly replaced on-screen by comedian Zachary Levi. Levi delivers a plausible but connection-lacking performance as the likeable Toby character.

The chipmunks voiced by Justin Long, Jesse McCartney and Matthew Gray Gubler and the Chipettes voiced by comedians Christina Applegate, Amy Poehler and Anna Faris were unrecognisable under the computer augmentation. Why pay the money for decent actors if you can't tell it's them?

The Verdict: Falling far short of filling children's insatiable appetite for talking animals, this careless low-budget enterprise trades in weak reiterations of subplots past. The Squeakquel is as entertaining as your standard breakfast cereal commercial and is as easily forgettable.

Published: The Queanbeyan Age
Date of Publication: 15/01/2010

But the sequel suffered from having a rather half baked plot in trying to pit one set of chipmunks over the other, and complicated itself by trying to do too much in too little, having to write off their human guardian Dave (Jason Lee) to replace him with nephew Toby (Zachary Levi) who's about as plain as a piece of cardboard, and the very tired Alvin versus his brothers in an all for one and one for none subplot involving his association with the football jocks in search for a higher popularity.Even the villain too was a repeat in having Ian (David Cross) make a comeback, in trying to exploit the Chipettes for his comeback after falling from grace in the first film, without the clunky corporate executive being corrupted by greed and money stemming from good intentions. Here he's manipulative in a child-like fashion through and through, and you can see his grand plot from a mile away when he tries to isolate one of the Chipettes whom he thinks will be a better solo artist at the expense of the rest. So it's a revisit of the same old themes of family togetherness over friends, or over careers, which got repeated twice for the different triplets. And it's either me, or somehow having the chipmunks all sounding alike (despite having a different voice cast) got to me this time round. The redeeming grace of having them sing and dance to contemporary pop tunes also took a nose dive here, having the number of performances got reduced, and of course the novelty of having such songs "munked" have lost their lustre.
However, having it released during this festive period would mean that all will get forgiven, and children will once again be thrilled by the all singing, all dancing chipmunks welcoming the festive cheer. There's a coda at the end of the film as well, so don't just head out the cinema once the credits start to roll.

I am not sure which of the two is better, so I am going to say that in my eyes this sequel is on the same level as its predecessor albeit with one improvement. Neither movie is as good as the timeless TV show or the wonderful Chipmunk Adventure, but in many ways more than one both are cute and harmless movies without trying to be 5-star masterpieces.
Alvin and the Chipmunks:The Squeakquel has cons that are similar to its predecessor. As with the first, the film is very predictable with some clichÃ (C)d human characters and situations, though in fairness a lot of animated/live action films do have that problem as well. Also it does have some hits and misses in the script with some jokes that parents might groan at. The film is rather short and rushed as well.
Faults aside, the film does have an improvement, the performance of Jason Lee as David. In the first he was miscast and out of his depth, here he is much more comfortable and relaxed. Visually and technically, I have little to fault it either. The photography and editing is crisp without being award-worthy, the location work is quite colourful and striking and the animation on the chipmunks again is spot on being very cute. The chipmunks are adorable with voices that are thankfully not irritating, and as with the first Alvin and the Chipmunks:The Squeakquel nails the personalities of the chipmunks, Theodore again being the best realised. And the soundtrack is very catchy, with tuneful melodies and sweet lyrics, which kids will love and adults will possibly tolerate too.
6/10

rt_summary: Now in the care of Dave Seville's nephew (Zachary Levi), chipmunks Alvin, Simon and Theodore take a break from pop-music stardom and return to school. Almost immediately, the tiny tunesmiths get the giant task of saving their school's music program by winning a battle-of-the-bands contest. Though the boys think winning it will be easy, romantic and musical sparks fly when they meet Brittany, Eleanor and Jeannette -- also known as The Chipettes.
